data.text: Bugs, Spiders, and Snakes in a Tarp Camp

For those of you who tarp camp, or even cowboy camp. Have you ever had issues with snakes, bugs, spiders, etc, crawling on you at night? I have a Big Agnes HV UL1 that Iâ€™m debating on just using the rainfly and groundsheet and not using the inner. But still deciding.

Issues??? Not necessarily, close encounters? Oh yeah... found a tarantula taking shelter inside my handlebar bag that I had left open overnight, and right next to my head. Scorpions crawling around right next to my footprint.
data.author: Marco A. Barron

data.text: Got bitten on lip by something one of the two times I didn't have a tent, whole mouth was huge and swollen for a long time. That said, the experience might have been uncimmon...... mosquitoes love me, so I cover up.
data.author: Chris Halle

data.text: Some hippy idiot with dreads tried telling me you didn't need a tent in the desert, then proceeded to show me where she got stung by a scorpion in the night.
data.author: Mike Calamonici

data.text: I only camp without some type netting when it is cold out. Years ago I always camped with just a wool blanket. I never had an issue back then.
data.author: Douglas Miner

data.text: I tarp camp in the fallâ€¦when bugs go back to hell where they belong
data.author: Nick Neleht

data.text: I never sleep without my tent inner. Bug bites can lead to infections and other first-aid situations, even if the bug itself is totally innocuous. Getting a bunch of them can be a miserable experience or catalyze allergic reactions later, and you never know for sure what tiny blessed friends are around you. It's just not worth the risk to me.
data.author: Carter AL

data.text: Agreed.
data.author: Matt Campbell

data.text: I only camp with my inner tent if itâ€™s too cold out for bugs. Even little mosquito & noseeum bites get very itchy on me, so I want to avoid them.
data.author: Cheryl Leskiw

data.text: Porcupines are the worst - no fear of anything, not even a baseball batâ€¦ Followed by skunks. Go hammock camping - less critter problems.
data.author: Dick Blomshield

data.text: I have never cMped without an inner. Mostly because the places I go have mosquitoes as big as jets... very unpleasant!
data.author: Angela M Freeman

data.text: same. I canâ€™t even believe itâ€™s a discussion.
data.author: Garth Fenton

data.text: I mean, I have heard lots of people who camp in the desert do so with a tarp or just a pad and ground sheet, but that is completely different than camping 8n the deep south. Lol!
data.author: Angela M Freeman

data.text: or in Alaska where I live. ðŸ¤£
data.author: Garth Fenton

data.text: lol! Yeah!
data.author: Angela M Freeman

data.text: I've tried the "fly only" option and had terrible condensation problems the next morning.
data.author: Greg Johnson

data.text: While desert camping in the southwest on more than one occasion i have had Scorpions, Velvet Ants and tarantulas climb in campside gear and shoes at night. Scorpions pack a pretty good sting but there are no poisonous species in the US. Never been bitten by a tarantula, they are harmless. Velvet Ants or Cow Killers are to be feared, they pack a wallop more painful than anything.
data.author: Michael Armalavage

data.text: the Arizona Bark Scorpion can kill.
data.author: Freeman Davis
Freeman Davis

data.text: I don't understand people who want to have a great day on the bike but then plan for a miserable night's sleep.
data.author: Andy Decker

data.text: omg yes. Nail. On. The. Head.
data.author: Garth Fenton

data.text: Well depends where you live, Australian outback or rural Ireland?
data.author: Patrick Gormley

data.text: I have not had issue with any unwelcome critters and have used tarps for years. I live in New Mexico which has its share of nasties (rattlesnakes, scorpions, etc) and I do sometimes think/worry about it. But once I am actually all set up, it feels less likely that something would find its way into my bag. So far, so good. It doesn't keep me up at night.
data.author: Wade Patterson

data.text: I've seen enough creepy crawlies in new Mexico that I won't even consider this. ðŸ˜…
data.author: Jonathon Slightam

data.text: Always tarp tent or cowboy camp. I've had ants and that's it.
data.author: Gary Brown

data.text: I had some spiders crawl through my tarp tent, and would routinely find ants in my sleeping bag, but I made sure to ride long enough during the day that I would sleep soundly during the night.
data.author: Jacob Buller

data.text: Yep, when in the Army woke up next to a guy with a six foot king brown snake cooled up on his chest, but that was only once out of hundreds of times. Now I am older and wiser and camp in a hammock....
data.author: Martyn Noakes

data.text: I've heard of this happening to someone too. I guess they like the warmth! Tent for me.
data.author: Kelly Nurton

data.text: So how did that play out?? I'm thinking I'd totally crap my pants..
data.author: Ross Douglas

data.text: we stood on top of an ASLAV and poked it with a vehicle antenna, luckily the guy didn't wake up, the snake slid off in to the bush. This was at Timber Creek in the NT. There were photos, but it was back in '94 so no idea what's happen to them.
data.author: Martyn Noakes

data.text: of course in the NT! It was a patient I had at work who told me this happened to him in the NT whilst sleeping in a swag.
data.author: Kelly Nurton

data.text: I suppose I was lucky, I was sleeping on the ground next to him ðŸ˜³ my wife was a nurse at Darwin Hospital at the time - the stories she can tell......
data.author: Martyn Noakes

data.text: Could also use a hammock. I rarely use a tarp, and almost never use a bugnet.
data.author: Leif Warner

data.text: I treated my double hammock with permethrin. All that extra fabric keeps them out.
data.author: James Folsom

data.text: No, no-one ever because all those things know itâ€™s rude to do that.. seriously??
data.author: Adam Macer

data.text: Yes had a raccoon lay on my chest it was awesome!
data.author: Frank Praznik Jr.

data.text: , mouse on stomach in hammock
data.author: Jim Goodwin

data.text: Iâ€™m guessing youâ€™re not in Scotland?
data.author: Katie McTavish

data.text: or Texas :-)
data.author: Simon Leicester

data.text: I was cowboy camping in Mexico an one of the lads got bitten by a snake. Had to leave the gear an go looking for a hospital. That's the only time in a 14 month trip
data.author: David Kitson

data.text: I just debated this for about 1 minute. Then I ordered a new tent. In Australia by the river we deal with Mosquitoes, Scorpions, Snakes, water rats. The list goes on. Considering Australia has some of the most venomous snakes in the world I think zipped up is the only option.
data.author: Craig Ward

data.text: Camping in the Southwestern states Iâ€™ve never had issues with bugs or snakes as long as I hang up my sleeping bag during the day and check my boots before I put them on. Iâ€™ve found plenty of scorpions under my ground cover but never had one invade my personal space. Mozzies and no-see-ums are a different problem but I try not to camp where they might be found, avoiding damp low-lying areas.
data.author: Gary Kelsey

data.text: I tend to camp in cooler weather when bugs and snakes are generally hibernating so few issues except a couple non-venomous snakes coming nearby. Iâ€™m careful to check shoes, socks, â€¦ But in tents, though careful with food/toiletries/etc., I have less luck with bears, raccoons, and skunks that clearly have associated people with food pawing at my tent at night. Never when Iâ€™m in a hammock or just on a tarp. I put bug spray on my hat or, when in areas with infectious disease, on mosquito netting and hammock. In Thailand, my fellow local travelers were more concerned about inadvertently being trampled by an elephant than anything else, so always slept a few feet off the ground (I doubted it would help much). I, on the other hand, wasnâ€™t too excited about walking amongst 5000 pound Asian longhorn steer to go to the bathroom.
data.author: Jim Lee

data.text: I donâ€™t want to wake up with a Mountain Lion licking the salt off my forehead! (or bugs on my face)
data.author: Karl Doll

data.text: Iâ€™m in Maine, Iâ€™m the Northeastern US. Not fond of ticks and their associated diseases, so itâ€™s a tent or bivy for me.
data.author: March Truedsson

data.text: Tarp and bivy, really great during the colder months. In the summer I need a tent.
data.author: Benjamin Michael Trister
